title: Australian lifestyle shift: City buyer demand grows for townhouse or terrace-style homes
text:
Goodbye quarter acre block, hello high rises and townhouses. The only way is up for Australia’s major population hubs according to industry experts.

While development sites suitable for high-density living continue to be the overall preferred option for developers, metropolitan buyers are hungry for townhouse or terrace style properties according to Knight Frank’s latest research.

Knight Frank’s Australian Residential Development Review reveals that in the 2018-19 financial year, high-density sites comprised 73.1 per cent of all residential development sites sold by volume, followed by low-density with a much smaller 20.9 per cent share.

Why millionaires are being priced out of these Aussie suburbs

“Medium-density or townhouse sites much suited to the downsizing population, and those priced out of the single dwelling market on the east coast, last recorded a 6 per cent share of Australian sites being sold for residential development in 2018-19,” said Michelle Ciesielski, a Knight Frank partner and head of residential research.

“In recent years, there has been substantially more land released for low-density in growth corridors of major cities. As a result, we’ve seen the uptick in first-home buyers. However, there is still elevated demand for those looking for townhouse stock, especially at the top-end of the market,” she said, adding that demand is outstripping supply.

“The strict lending criteria for buyers has now been loosened, but access to traditional finance is still difficult for many local and offshore developers which has resulted in many projects put on hold,” she said.

“As a result of project marketing being postponed, and in many cases construction commencements, the pipeline of new apartments tapers back significantly over the next three years, potentially not supporting the population growth projected for major Australian cities.”

Inside Michael Jordan’s mountain mansion

Chris Johnson, Urban Taskforce Australia’s CEO said the shape of metropolitan skylines has already started to change and communities need to identify the changing great Australian dream.

“There is a shift to a shared urban lifestyle in apartments with 30 per cent of Sydney homes being strata at the 2016 Census. Since then we have built a lot of apartments, but for the last year there has been a big slow down,” he said.

As population levels in Sydney and Melbourne move toward the 5 million mark, Mr Johnson said Australia needs to follow the property path of other global cities.

“Cities like London and New York have gone through similar tensions as they grow above 4 or 5 million people and low density means long commute times. So, while there will be times when communities react against high rise apartment living, I believe it is here to stay, especially in Sydney and a number of demographic groups prefer this more cosmopolitan way of living.”
description: Substantial changes to how Australians want to live are set to remake our metropolitan areas into cities akin to New York and London.
